business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m. and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, do you recall telling the Senate yesterday, in relation to your Pan Australian interests, `I have no knowledge whatsoever of any investments,' `I had no record of any investments in Pan Aust.,' `I did not know about it'? Minister, had you forgotten that on 17 November 1995, five months before you became a minister, you chaired a meeting of QCMM and involved yourself in the detail of the disposal by QCMM of Terra Firma interests to Pan Australian? Had you forgotten that the discussion on the disposal involved Bob Bryan, current chair of Pan Australian, and that the meeting determined a continued role for QCMM and Kiskin in Pan Australian? How could you claim ignorance of your interests in Pan Australian? Minister, haven't you just misled the Senate again?

—I am delighted to answer this, Senator. You have led with your chin on this. Before I do so, let me say, quite categorically, I have no problem with you taking me on in this place, but what I do object to, with my wife walking down the corridor with you and Senator Robert Ray, when you hissed my wife just about 10 or 15 minutes ago.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The Senate will come to order. Senators will cease interjecting.
—On a point of order, Madam President: that is a despicable and contemptible lie from Senator Parer.
—Order! Senators on my right will cease interjecting. It is very important that I can hear what is being said.

—Madam President, not only have I not hissed Senator Parer's wife, whom I do not know, have never met and would not know what she looks like; I have never hissed anyone in my life. I demand that that despicable and contemptible lie be withdrawn by that incompetent no-hoper of a minister.
—Order!

—On a point of order, Madam President: not only was that not a point of order, but it was a flagrant breach of the standing orders to talk about `a despicable lie' and to impugn the integrity of Senator Parer, when Senator Faulkner well knows that there will be an opportunity after question time for him to make a personal explanation. But under the guise of taking a point of order, to then abuse other people and impugn their integrity is simply out of order.

—Madam President, on the point of order. Senator Parer was asked a specific question. He did not answer it. He went on to other areas and, in those circumstances, I think senators are entitled to point out that he is in gross error in this accusation. He has my absolute word, and he has Senator Faulkner's word, that we do not even know what his wife looks like, let alone would we ever stoop to abuse her in a corridor of this parliament.
—You liar! You liar!
—Senator Faulkner, I ask you to withdraw that.
—Madam President, I withdraw. I would not know what Senator Parer's wife looked like and I would not hiss at anyone.
—Order! There is no point of order. There is an appropriate—

—Order! I will not tolerate the shouting that is going on across the chamber at the present time. All senators who are doing so can consider themselves warned. There is no point of order. There is an appropriate time to debate these matters. Senator Parer, I draw your attention to the question that was asked and ask you to address it.

—Madam President, as I indicated, Senator Faulkner led with his chin on this. Regarding the acquisition and sale of shares by QCMM Kiskin, the shares were acquired in October 1996. I had resigned from the boards of both Kiskin and QCMM by that time. People are coming in here day after day saying, `You have an ongoing relationship with the management and operation of this company.' If I had that, I would have known about that fact. They were not acquired until after I became a minister.

answer.para: Regarding the other shares that were referred to—that is, QCMM (ESP)—let me put it to you this way: these shares were acquired in 1994 and they were transferred to another company not related to me or the company involved in September 1995. Hence my comment yesterday—which took me by surprise—when I said that I really did not know that they had shares in regards to Pan Aust.

What did happen with ESP was that, while all the shares were acquired and rights were sought, the company then incorrectly issued back to ESP rights which should have gone to a company called Lacetal. I have gone to some lengths to find out the background to that. I have the letter here from the then solicitor of QCMM (ESP) to the solicitor for Lacetal laying it all out—that all the shares were transferred to Lacetal, that Lacetal sought to exercise some rights, that without any approval from ESP, or in fact without notifying ESP, Lacetal made application for those shares and they went to the wrong company, and that ESP only became aware of those shareholdings in July 1996, after I had been involved with the board of either QCMM, Kiskin or ESP.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, in order to demonstrate that you have not misled the Senate, will you obtain minutes of QCMM meetings which you have attended, at which Pan Australian was discussed, and will you table those for the benefit of senators?
—I made it very clear that, when I resigned as a director and chairman of all those companies, I did what everyone should do: I disposed of all those minutes. These are private company minutes.
—I said: would you obtain the minutes?
—What date are you talking about?
—You know exactly what I said.

—I can only repeat exactly what I said: that ESP acquired the shares in 1994. It sold them in 1995. QCMM Kisken, in fact, acquired the shares. The transaction occurred in October 1996. They went on further in the report I have got that the shares were subject to restriction agreement of the Australian Stock Exchange which was not lifted until October 1997 and, as soon as the restriction agreement was lifted, negotiations commenced to dispose of those shares. Ultimately, the shares were sold in a market transaction on 2 February 1998.

—My question without notice is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will the minister inform the Senate of the government's generous offer to the states on funding for public hospitals? Will the minister also advise whether the patients of Australia will be affected by the states' behaviour at last week's Premiers Conference?

—This is a very important issue, and there can be no doubt that the coalition government's health care funding offer was a generous one. It was not only generous but also innovative. I might look briefly at the facts.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of noise in the chamber is unacceptably high.

—In the last five years, the Commonwealth has spent $27.3 billion on the Commonwealth-state health care agreements. The forward estimates show that this funding would rise to $30.3 billion over the next five years. In other words, over the next five years the states will get an extra $3 billion, which is already budgeted for. But on top of that—and this is the important point—on top of the $27 billion plus the $3 billion, we have committed an extra $1.5 billion in the base funding over the next five years; an extra $750 million for funding for veterans being fully treated in public hospitals; $500 million for initiatives in efficiency and effectiveness in hospitals, particularly in the area of information technology; and another $120 million on waiting lists in public hospitals. Therefore, what we are offering over the forward estimates is $2.9 billion of new money. That is a 6.9 per cent real increase in the first year of funding, moving to a 15.4 per cent real increase over the five years of the agreement.

answer.para: A big advantage of this agreement, and one that stands in stark contrast to the previous 1993 agreement under Labor, is that we have given a commitment that, if the level of private health insurance coverage drops, we will add $83 million a year to the health care agreements for any one per cent reduction in the number of people covered by private hospital insurance. Therefore, contrary to what the states are saying, we have provided a safeguard in terms of funding. This is on top of the $600 million a year—or $450 a year subsidy for families—that the government provides via the private health insurance incentive scheme. So, while some states complain about waiting lists, the ACT, having signed an in principle agreement, will this week be able to draw $551,000, which will fund an extra 200 admissions.

The Howard government is retaining Medicare, increasing funding by $2.9 billion, addressing the shortfalls in private health insurance and cutting waiting lists. What that amounts to is a greater contribution by the Commonwealth, in fact, than the contribution by the states. That could be starkly contrasted with what the Labor Party did in government, although it is interesting that, when the Labor Party was in government, even it was saying that it was putting more money in when the states were cutting it.

You might remember former Minister Lawrence, who said, `It's not just that we are putting in more, the states are actually taking funding out.' So the states were taking money out under Labor. They have continued to take it out. Not only have we done what Labor did but also we have upped the funding in the substantial areas that I have shown, and we have provided the safeguard in relation to private insurance. What more could reasonably be expected of the Commonwealth? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand that, under the previous government, the number of people in private health insurance dropped from around 70 per cent to 35 per cent. Will you advise the Senate what the coalition government is doing to arrest that slide?

—That is right. That is where the real problem lies. Under Labor, private health insurance premiums increased by an average of 12 per cent over 10 years. From 1986 to 1988, under Labor, premiums went up 40 per cent. In 1983, almost 70 per cent of Australians had private health insurance. By the end of Labor, it had dropped to 35 per cent and there were 100,000 people on waiting lists.

answer.para: What is Labor's response to our initiatives? They are opposed to the surcharge on higher income earners to support the health system, and they are opposed to the extra $600 million we are putting in to support taxpayers to maintain private health insurance. So what is Labor's alternative? Of course nobody knows Labor's alternative. All we know is that they would take the money out of what we are putting in to subsidise private health care.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Hill!
—And they would take the money out of the surcharge that we are putting on higher income earners—a disaster.
—Order! Senator Hill, if you were addressing your remarks through the chair, you would have known that I was calling you to order. Your time had expired.

—My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, I refer to your statement yesterday that you propose to pass your shares in your family trustee company to members of your family. Are you aware of the Prime Minister's statement on radio 2GB on 14 October 1996, when he was asked by Derryn Hinch, `Well, what if I put shares into a family trust that I have no say in—just my wife and my children have access to,' and the Prime Minister replied, `Well, the guidelines don't allow you to do that if you owned the shares at the time the guidelines operate'? Minister, isn't it the case that you have not in any way removed your breach of the Prime Minister's code of conduct? Isn't it also the case that your continued presence on the coalition government front bench continues to highlight your government's absolute lack of standards and absolute lack of probity?
—I think the Prime Minister has made it very clear indeed what he means by that. The Derryn Hinch one would have been read as to the wife and children—meaning, of course, dependent children.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of noise is far too high. Senators on my left will cease interjecting.

—Not only have I divested myself of all interests and all directorships, but my wife has done the same as well. The people who it has been transferred to are all adult children. They are all adults, the youngest of whom is 25 years of age.

answer.para: It is interesting to look at just what the opposition have claimed over the past little while. They have alleged that the trust could have disposed of its interests. Wrong. They have alleged that I have had talks of a private business nature in Japan on an official visit. Wrong, and proved by official minutes. It is an outrageous imputation. They have alleged that I have a conflict of interest in the Native Title Amendment Bill. Wrong. We have the opposition over there talking about apologies.

talk.start.para: —You do have. You do have a conflict.
—Senator Cook, you will have an opportunity to debate this at an appropriate time, and it is not now.

—The opposition tried—and I think I have absolutely demolished you today—to establish some absurd, obscure link between me and a mining exploration company called Pan Australian. It is perfectly clear that any involvement between any of those companies and Pan Australian was either completed before I resigned as chairman and before I became a minister or occurred afterwards, when I would have had no knowledge of it.

answer.para: When is Senator Faulkner going to admit that I have not now, not ever, at any time, had any conflict of interest? When are you going to tell us what your policies are on the issues that really confront Australia? We have not heard one policy from the Labor Party. All they have been doing since we came back into this parliament is muckrake. They tried to unearth scandals in the Natural Heritage Trust. That went nowhere, so they thought, `Well, we'll have a go at this bloke.' I am yet to hear one example of a conflict of interest that I have had in my position as minister. I think it is about time Senator Faulkner and others started apologising to me and my family.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. We are aware minister that the Prime Minister has redefined his guidelines. Are you aware that those guidelines say:

question.para: The transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment?

While you are at it, could you indicate to the Senate whether either the Prime Minister or the Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet certified your revised trust arrangements as being in compliance with the Prime Minister's `Guide on Key Elements of Ministerial Responsibility'?

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister is fully aware of the action I have taken to totally divest myself—not, I might say, for any conflict of interest and not, I might say, before—
—Well, why did you do it?

—Senator Ray asked why I did it. I will tell you why I did it: because it puts legally what was actually occurring in practice over a great number of years, and I said that right from the word go. My wife had managed that trust for years and for very good reasons. The very good reasons are that, when one has families like this, it is most important, I would say, that the wife is totally over the financial matters in relation to the family. Some people on that side might not agree with that. You might prefer the wives to be somewhere else, but let me tell you that that has been my philosophy for many years and it is a very important one when it comes to raising and caring for a family.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, I draw your attention to claims that some 1,300 people on public hospital waiting lists for elective surgery are missing out every week because the states are refusing to sign the Medicare agreement. Will you confirm these figures and will you provide specific figures for my state, New South Wales?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Sandy Macdonald for the question, which is very apposite considering the negotiations that are going on at the moment. I can confirm Senator Macdonald's figures because they are absolutely true. The Commonwealth is offering a $120 million waiting list bonus to the states if they sign the Medicare agreement. Until they do sign, they will be missing out on this bonus.

answer.para: All of us are aware of the waiting list problems in the states. I would have thought that Senator Faulkner, representing the state of New South Wales, would be getting onto his Premier to bring home to him the fact that New South Wales is missing out on $1.4 million a week instead of pursuing a relentless campaign against my friend and colleague here which has gone nowhere. He should be concerned about the waiting lists of dying people in his own state and doing something about that instead of carrying on with this futile exercise.

In addition, for every one per cent drop in private health insurance, the federal government is putting in an $83 million extra bonus. What did the Labor Party do when they were in power? There was an agreement that, when it dropped below two per cent, they would reconvene and discuss the agreement. I hammered them at that time about why it was not being done. They reneged on the agreement at the time. There was a two per cent drop and they took no notice of it. They never took any notice of their own agreement. At least we keep our agreements. We have offered an $83 million bonus. But they scoff on the other side. I would like to read them something, and they might take notice of this:

But as every one of them pulls out, the profile worsens for those left in. The sick, obviously, are going to stay in, so the premiums go up. More and more people get pushed out. As they get pushed out, the premiums go up more. It just feeds on itself the whole time.
This was said by the then Labor health minister, Senator Richardson, who, I think, sat in this seat. On 8 December 1983 he also said:

There are a couple of obvious things you should do about it. One of them is to talk about a levy for those on higher incomes. As you would no doubt be aware, my Prime Minister does not agree, neither do some people on the left of the party, but they have a different reason from him. He wants to keep it universal; they want a higher levy for higher income earners with no opt-out if you are in private health insurance. The ACTU have that same policy.

What did we do? We brought in a $450 rebate for low and middle income earners so they would retain their private health insurance so it would take the pressure off the public hospitals and reduce the waiting lists. There is one government that has accepted it: the ACT government. And the Labor Party vote—
Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is too much noise. If senators were addressing the chair, they would notice when I am attempting to attract their attention.

—They might well scoff, but their vote went down to 27 per cent in the ACT. Chief Minister Kate Carnell signed the agreement. There are an extra 210 admissions per week in the ACT as a result of that agreement being signed. No wonder the Labor vote went down to 27 per cent in the ACT. She showed that she had the leadership.

answer.para: The people on the waiting lists should be getting in touch with their state governments and asking why they are on these waiting lists and why they will not sign the Medicare agreement which would mean that an extra 1,300 patients per week could be admitted. Some 1,300 patients could be admitted Australia-wide if the states signed the Medicare agreement and got on with it. As my leader said, we are giving an extra $3 billion—a 15 per cent increase—over five years. So I can see no reason why they do not sign the agreement.
Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is too much conversation across the chamber. It makes it very hard to hear.
—In Senator Faulkner's own state, it means an extra 451 patients could be admitted to the public hospitals each week. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, will you further provide details of the number of patients on waiting lists missing out on treatment because their particular states and territories have refused to sign the Medicare agreement?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Sandy Macdonald for the supplementary question because I am happy to do so. For example, apart from New South Wales, which I mentioned before was 451, the other states make up the difference. The big argument that cuts the states' argument down is that bed stays have gone down by a third in the last five years. So they are calling for extra money when, in fact, the bed stays have gone down by a third. People are only staying an average of fewer than four days per episode.

answer.para: Senator Cook interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is true. It has gone down because of technology. Patients are going in and out of the public hospitals faster. The states are wanting extra money when, in fact, the bed stays have gone down. So that cuts their argument down by a third straightaway. We are giving a 15 per cent increase over that period. When the Labor Party came in, they were against private health insurance. They tried to destroy it. Now they are crowing because it has gone down so low. As I said, Senator Faulkner should get onto his own Premier and do something about it. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, I refer to your failure to declare your holding of 44 shares in QCMM (ESP), which you value at $56,300, on the basis that it is, in your words, akin to a superannuation scheme. What could be plainer, Minister, than the requirement for senators to declare `shareholdings in public and private companies, including holding companies, indicating the name of the company or companies'? Where do the Senate standing orders excuse senators from declaring their interests in companies that may be akin to a superannuation scheme? Minister, is this not just another pathetic excuse to justify your concealment of your interest in QCMM (ESP) and, through it, in Pan Australian?

—The latter one with regard to Pan Australian has been totally debunked. I think I have made that very clear right from the beginning. The ESP shares in Pan Australian were actually sold by the company in September 1995, prior to my ever coming. With regard to the other one, I have answered this a number of times in the Senate. This was called an employee share plan. The whole idea was that certain profits from the company were to be put into this plan for its employees and its directors.
—It's a tax lurk.

—`It's a tax lurk,' he says. Senator, this involves moneys going into the company on which, eventually, when that money is taken out on retirement, full tax will be paid. There is no way of avoiding tax on it. Meanwhile, while that company has that money, the same as any sort of life benefit or accumulation fund—

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—I would say that probably the only difference between superannuation and this one, if my taxation is correct, is that for any income that is made by ESP in fact company tax is paid whereas with the mutual funds and things like that there is a specialised rate of tax. But the way it operates is that moneys go from the profits into the fund and, when that money is eventually taken out on retirement, full taxation is paid.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you then guarantee that QCMM (ESP) has no shareholdings—
—Order! Senators on my right will cease interjecting while a question is being asked.
—Thank you, Madam President. Minister, can you then guarantee that QCMM (ESP) has no shareholdings in companies that operate in areas of your portfolio interest?
—Senator, in response to your question, I do not know. I will tell you why I do not know. This particular fund is managed by one of the—
—You can't be serious.
—Senator Faulkner, you have asked the question. Senator Parer has the opportunity to answer it.

—Speak slowly, they say. If my memory is correct, and I will just check to make sure it is, I think that the units in ESP are about 44 out of about three or four million or something. I have never had any involvement in what that company puts money into or what it does not put money into. I know the line you are getting at—that somehow I was aware of this; therefore there could have been a conflict of interest. Let me tell you, Senator, I have no control over it and never have had any control over it, and what shareholdings it has I do not know.

—My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, on Sunday, the South Australian Liberal Premier backed an earlier call from the Democrats—
—Order! Senators will stop shouting across the chamber; I wish to hear Senator Lees's question. Please start again, Senator Lees.

—Thank you, Madam President. Minister, on Sunday, the South Australian Premier backed an earlier call from the Australian Democrats for an independent financial audit of the public health system. I ask today: will your government respond to this call, which would at least serve as a circuit breaker in the current ludicrous stand-off between Liberal state and federal health ministers? Secondly, will your government also consider reinstating the gun buy-back levy in order to provide the additional funds necessary to keep our public health system going and, in particular, to repair the backlog of funding until such time as the independent audit is complete?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Senator Lees is well known for her interest in health care. Senator Lees might follow her predecessor as Leader of the Democrats by moving into the Labor Party so that the standard of knowledge on health care will go up in both places.
—Senator Herron, I ask you to withdraw that. It was an attack on Senator Lees that ought not be made.

—I withdraw. Senator Lees well knows that the posturing that goes on by the states always occurs when the Medicare agreement is renegotiated. That is what it is about. There is no crisis in this regard. The fact of the matter is that, every time the Medicare agreement is renegotiated, the states come along, cap in hand, cry poor and talk about all the problems that have occurred.

answer.para: For example, Dr Wooldridge pointed out that the money they are asking for would be equivalent to 300,000 admissions. It is simply that there are not enough patients to fill those beds if that were granted. What the states are doing is exactly the same as what they did when the Labor Party was in power. I reread a speech that I gave in the Senate at that time; you could just change the names and you have the same issues going today as five years ago.

For example, New South Wales reduced its own source funding on hospitals in 1993-94 by five per cent in real terms, although it has since had to increase funding due to the appalling inefficiency of its hospitals. Victoria reduced its spending by 23 per cent in 1993-94 and is still spending 18 per cent less in real terms then it did in 1992-93. Queensland reduced spending by 15 per cent in 1993-94 and did not begin spending more than in 1992-93 in real terms until 1995-96. Western Australia made a similar reduction in 1993-94 and has yet to return to 1992-93 levels of spending.

Your own state, Senator Lees, reduced its spending somewhat in 1993-94 and is still slightly below real 1992-93 levels of funding. Tasmania reduced its own source spending by 25 per cent in real terms in 1993-94, and it has since reduced it by a further five per cent. So, this argument, which I heard five years ago and which Senator Lees heard five years ago, is the same sort of argument, and they keep repeating it.

Senator Robert Ray asked me how many people in my own state of Queensland need not be stuck on waiting lists if the bonus were accepted. It is 238 in Queensland. In Tasmania it is 34; in Western Australia, 121; in Victoria, 328; in the Northern Territory nine patients per week—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order on relevance. Minister, I specifically asked you about an audit, not for further explanation of the Commonwealth's point of view. What are you going to do about the audit that has been asked for?

—Madam President, I pointed out at the beginning of my answer that there was no need for an audit because of the facts that I have just put on the table. The audit is being continually done. There is no need to rush out and have it. These facts are available to everybody. They are published every year in the health department's report. There is no crisis. It is normal for the states to come with their hands out wanting more money. I do not believe there is anything abnormal about that. They do it every time the Medicare agreement is renegotiated.

answer.para: The second part of the question was in relation to the gun levy. That was a one-off situation, as I understand it, but I am happy to refer it to the minister. My immediate response would be that that is unlikely.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister. I think you have just given us a very good example of why we need the audit. That is the Commonwealth's perspective and, while obviously there are waiting list problems, all of this money is not for waiting lists; it is to address the backlog of maintenance and the new technology that is needed in hospitals. I ask you again, Minister, to stop all this buck passing between Commonwealth and state, which, as you said has been going on for five and more years. Why don't we have a full audit of the public health system to look at where the pressure points are, what the real needs are, and then we can work out where we can get the money from?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —It must be evident to Senator Lees that there is no need for that. We all know that we inherited this mess from the Labor Party when we took power two years ago. What is their policy? What is the Democrats' policy in relation to health care? Where is the Labor Party policy on anything, let alone health care? They got it down to the depths that it is in now.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I take a point of order which again goes to relevance. I do not want to hear about the Labor Party policy. I am asking for your policy and what you are going to do about the state of our public hospitals. Have you visited a public hospital, Minister, in the last few weeks to see the problems yourself?
—There is no point of order, but if there were fewer interjections there would be fewer distractions for Senator Herron.
—The answer to the question is yes.

—My question is to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, isn't it true that, in the material you contrived to prevent us from analysing prior to question time yesterday, your department lists three decisions you made in relation to the coal export facilitation program—the CEF program. Bearing in mind your lucrative interest in the Jellinbah coal mine, which exports to Japan, isn't there a very obvious conflict of interest in you, firstly, making decisions in relation to a $1.49 million program and, secondly, in the words of your department, `develop the relationships needed to address coal trade and investment barriers and to open doors for Australian industry'? Why then didn't you delegate to your senior minister your decisions of 15 August 1996 to approve the general policy direction of the CEF; of 13 December 1996 to approve the order of priority and general funding levels of various elements of the program; and of 14 January to approve an adjusted structure for the program? (Time expired)
—Madam President, just before I answer that question I would like to add to an answer which I gave to Senator Faulkner before.
—Well, do it at the end of question time. Answer my question!
—No, I will do it.

—On a point of order, Madam President: you know that it is competent for a minister to add to a question or correct a answer given in question time, but at the end of question time. I do think that on this occasion it is clear that you ought to direct Senator Parer to answer Senator Cook's question and, of course, Senator Parer will have the capacity to do that at the end of question time.

—The appropriate time to add to answers is at the end of question time. It may be relevant to this answer and be a part of it, but the preliminary comment of adding to the answer given to Senator Faulkner's question would have perhaps been best left out.
—The comment is that I was totally unaware of any shareholding in ESP, but it was advised to me yesterday—
—Madam President, on a point of order: that is not relevant to my question. Will you answer my question?
—Resume your seat, Senator.

—It was advised to me yesterday that all shares held by ESP had been sold in order to take advantage of a real estate opportunity and this took place prior to any of this issue being raised in parliament.

answer.para: Getting on to your question, Senator Cook, let me say this: these coal export facilitation activities are generic to the whole coal industry. They are not specific to a particular mine. They are generic to the whole industry. If you want to take a look at them one after another, we have the facilitation program, which was developed with an annual budget—you are quite right—of $1.4 million.

There was an industry mission to India. It had no relationship to the mine in which my family trust had an interest. They have never been to India. It is not the sort of thing they would take to India. It is not a market for their coal. But it is in the interests of the whole coal industry. You are saying to me that simply because a family trust was in place that had an interest in a particular mine that happens to sell a particular type of coal into a couple of markets like Japan, some part of Europe and some part of South America—which is where it was when I left it, unless it has changed—there should not be a coal mission to India. Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of conversation in the chamber is far too high for people, including me, to hear clearly. I ask senators to take a seat in the chamber.

—Senator Parer, resume your seat please. The level of noise is unacceptably high. Order, order!

—As I said, it is a matter of commonsense in these things and people have to make reasonable judgments. I just think that, from my own perspective, when it comes to the decision making process that revolves around my portfolio, there has not been a conflict of interest and there will not a conflict of interest.

Perhaps you could explain, Minister, why you have not adopted the procedure that was outlined to the Senate by Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government, then Leader of the Opposition? —Senator Faulkner has leave to make a statement. It was not restrict ed to that matter. Senator Faulkner was granted leave to make a statement.

—I was about to make the point—and I think it is an important one—that over the years I have been in this place I think I have very rarely, if ever, objected to a statement that has been made about me. I do not claim to be sensitive or have a thin skin. On this occasion I did during question time because the statement that Senator Parer made was utterly untrue. It is only because of that and because of the nature of the statement that I took a point of order and reacted the way I did. I accept the explanation that Senator Parer has made and, on this occasion, let me say I appreciate the fact that he has made it.

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —No, it is serious. He was prepared to imply corruption on their part. He now knows that that was totally unfounded. We now know that he was defaming two dead persons, apart from the live Baillieus. If he has any sort of decency, he would come in here and apologise. I'm sorry that I defamed you,' then we can all start afresh tomorrow and feel much better about it.

—by leave—The matter that Senator Parer mentioned at the start of question time is all over the news bulletins right throughout Australia at the moment and my office has been rung. I am sure Mrs Parer may have taken offence. I can assure Senator Parer that neither Senator Faulkner nor I, unfortunately, have met your wife or know what she looks like. talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), to questions without notice asked today, relating to the financial interests of Senator Parer.

Both Senator Parer and the Prime Minister have claimed today that Senator Parer's companies sold their stake in Pan Australian Resources in 1995. It would appear that this claim is contradicted by current Australian Securities Commission documents which show both QCMM Group (ESP) and Kiskin on behalf of the Parer family trust as current shareholders in Pan Australian Resources Pty Ltd. We will be interested to hear Senator Parer's explanation in relation to that matter.

Senator Parer has been a minister in the Howard government now for just on two years. Let us have a look at what his performance has been in terms of meeting the very low standards of ministerial conduct that were put in place by Mr Howard at the start of his government's term.

The Prime Minister's own code requires ministers to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business in any area of their portfolio. But Senator Parer, the minister for coal, held a $2 million interest in a coalmine through his family trust, personally held shares in an associated employee company, and also, as the minister for just about very other resource, held shares in Pan Australian Resources. That is the first breach of the Prime Minister's discredited code.

The code also states that the transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment. But Senator Parer now purports to satisfy the code by passing his trust holdings to his adult children. And this does not fit any reasonable reading of the Prime Minister's words. That is Senator Parer's second breach of the code.

The code also states that the minister should not intentionally mislead the parliament or the public. Senator Parer has misled this parliament and the public many times by not declaring his trust holdings as required by the parliament, by not declaring his personal shareholdings, by repeatedly failing to declare these interests when speaking or voting on relevant matters in the Senate on bills and legislation, by numerous public statements that he had fully disclosed everything when that was never the case, and also by his public statements that he never personally held shares in mining companies. That is five more breaches of the Prime Minister's own discredited code.

The code also says that ministers should avoid giving any appearance of using public office for private profit. But Senator Parer used a taxpayer funded trip to Japan to hold discussions with the two joint venturer partners in his coalmine, who, as the major customers for his coal, increased their coal orders from Jellinbah by over 25 per cent after that trip. That is breach No. 7 of the Prime Minister's code.

Of course, the code also says that a minister must not engage in any professional practice or in the daily work of any business. But Senator Parer was dobbed in by Mr Harold Shand as having had ongoing contact with Mr Shand as the managing director of the coalmine operator and as having had conversations that included discussion of industry matters.

As far as we are concerned, they are just eight examples of the minister having misled the Australian public about his personal interests conflicting with his public duties. We say that this code is discredited, that the Prime Minister is utterly discredited, that Senator Parer is completely discredited, and so is the government whom he represents in this chamber. He is so discredited that it really is a gall for him to remain a minister. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —What absolute hypocrisy on the part of the Australian Labor Party yet again. When the greatest rorter and conflicter of interests in recent times in this parliament, the then Leader of the Labor Party, was conflicting in his interests over the piggery, over tax and over the Commonwealth Bank for a long period of time, there was not a whimper from the Australian Labor Party. So it is obvious why the Labor Party has lost this issue.

speech.para: I wish to oppose the motion before the chair—that is, that we take note of the answers from Senator Parer—and wish to move as an amendment that we take notice of the answers given by Senator Kemp and Senator Herron, because those answers and those questions were about the real issues confronting the Australian public, not the continual muckraking and slime dredging by the Labor Party. talk.start.para: —Senator Macdonald, are you seriously moving those amendments?
—Yes, if I can.
—No, they are not in order, because they do not relate to the subject matter that is before the chair.
—The subject matter before the chair is that we take notice of the answer from Senator Parer. My amendment is that we take notice of the answer by Senator Herron.
—Note or notice?
—Note—take note of.
—It is moving it to a different motion. Therefore, it is not in order.

—The motion before the chair is that we take note of the answers given by Senator Parer—just that we take note of his answers. My amendment is that we take note of the answers given not by Senator Parer but by Senator Herron. And it is simply a motion to take note of answers. I am suggesting that the motion should be amended to delete reference to the answer by Senator Parer and include Senator Herron's name in its stead .
—And I am saying—

—Madam Deputy President, could I suggest a way of approaching it. One of the concerns is that the whole half-hour could be taken up before we actually get to another opportunity to take note of an answer by Senator Herron. So if Senator Macdonald is allowed to simply add to it then that enables him to deal with this at the same time. —I realise that the Labor Party are just trying to stop me talking about the real issue confronting Australia, which is health. We want to talk about health.

speech.para: This issue of taking note of Senator Parer's answer is quite ridiculous. Not even the Democrats raised this issue today, which shows how absolutely irrelevant it is. But the real issue, as all Australians know, is the health issue and what happened last week that Senator Herron and Senator Kemp have spoken about. It is with some regret that the state premiers left the meeting on health because, as all Australians should know, the Commonwealth was giving a 15 per cent increase—in real terms over a five year period—in health funding.

Furthermore, as the minister, Dr Wooldridge, has been saying, this government has negotiated an agreement that provides reimbursement of some $83 million a year to the states for any one per cent of further reduction in the number of people covered by private health insurance. Now these are the real issues which show what this government is doing to make sure that the health of all Australians is assured. The Labor Party do not want to talk about this health issue because their priority is to abolish—and take away from Australian families—the $450 a year subsidy that the Howard government introduced in the last year.

This is the only policy that the Labor Party have enunciated. You ask the Labor Party what their policies are on anything else, and you get former senator Gareth Evans talking about negative gearing. That was countermanded within six hours by his leader. So there is a policy vacuum over there in the Labor Party. Tell us what your policy is on health. As Senator Kemp has mentioned, it seems that your policy is to spend an extra $6.2 billion, with no indication of where that money is coming from. It is pretty obvious. And Senator Carr, we know that it is part of your socialist left philosophy to increase taxes all the time to pay for this additional $6 billion that your spokesman wants to spend. That is the difference—we have policies, you have none. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Isn't it interesting that no Liberal opposite is willing to get up and defend Senator Parer on the specifics. We have got a daily event here called the Parer sprint. As soon as a question on Senator Parer is noted, we have a great sprint outside the chamber— led by Senator Parer—every day. And the best they can do is send in the Claude Erskine-Brown of the Liberal Party—Senator Ian Macdonald—to run off a few distracting lines.

speech.para: As an Australian who wants his country to do well—who never actually wants his country to be run by a second-rate Prime Minister—I feel just a little humiliated by his behaviour in the last two or three weeks. It has been demeaning to watch a Prime Minister changing, day by day, the definition of his own principles. I read in the newspaper the other day that Groucho Marx remarked, when someone rejected the principles he was putting forward: `Well, I've got another bunch of principles in here. How would you like to buy them?' That is the approach we have had.

We have had an approach whereby Senator Short and Senator Gibson were dismissed from office—by way of their own resignations—because they were involved in a perceived conflict of interest. That was a definition that the Prime Minister and Senator Hill himself constantly used in this chamber between 10 October 1996 and 15 October 1996—that Senator Short and Senator Gibson had to relinquish their offices because they were involved in a perceived conflict of interest. Then the definition drifts off, over time, to an apparent conflict of interest. But by the time we get to March 1998, it is an actual conflict of interest. And then there is a sub-interpretation put on it. It has to actually involve enrichment of the minister. So this definition of conflict of interest has changed constantly.

When the minister gets sprung, the minister panics. The minister decides to cut his losses—or his profits, in this case—cut those and move it all away from himself. He then goes into flagrant breach of another Prime Ministerial directive that says you cannot transfer those sort of assets to your family—it does not say dependent children here; it says family—or a nominee, implying that it goes well beyond family. So having done that, what does the Prime Minister's office do, but say: `Oh, sorry fellas, what we mean there is dependent children,' when it is quite clear from the Derryn Hinch interview that they did not mean dependent children then.

We have a Prime Minister constantly changing his definition to fit the behaviour of his ministers. If Senator Parer does not come out of this very well, at least he comes out of it a lot better than the Prime Minister of Australia. After all, these principles were tabled first of all in this parliament as something very new: as a fresh approach. A puffed-up Prime Minister comes in and says, `I am going to set higher standards than the previous government.' When you go to the estimates committee and find out where all these principles came from, we find out it comes from the previous government's cabinet handbook; so there was nothing new here, this was just a cheap stunt by a Prime Minister trying to grab the high moral ground. Well, give him a tick, he got the brownie points for it.

But what happens the moment ministers start to transgress? He does not dismiss them: Short and Prosser resign. This is not a sacking Prime Minister, as he likes to make out. The only person this Prime Minister sacks are his own resigned staff members, so they can get a higher payout than would have been the case if he had accepted their resignations. We have a weak Prime Minister totally unable to enforce his own standards. All we get from him is, `This is the politics of envy.' This is the line we get from those opposite. We got it again today about trade union officials. Look who we have got sitting opposite: a lawyer in the number one position and a lawyer in the number two position; Senator Newman—a lawyer; Senator Vanstone—a lawyer—four in a row, when they are talking about representing the widespread community. Senator Ellison makes five out of eight. All you have got is a surgeon as the odd man out. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, Senator Ray spoke of his embarrassment, but he should have looked at his own backbenchers when he addressed the chamber. There is one particular senator. It has all the look of the day after the attack on the Baillieus and the Natural Heritage Trust. They deserted the frontbench attack then and they have done the same now. This has all the look. The whole of question time has completely conked out. I am happy to jump up and join my colleague Senator Ian Macdonald. He made the absolutely correct point that this is not the issue of the day; this is not the issue that is biting out in society. The real issue is related to policy. The sale of Telstra has been the No. 1 head issue.

speech.para: It was only yesterday that Senator Abetz made this point and made it very well. An article in the Financial Review reported that of the 583 questions asked last year, in 1997, in this chamber, only 79 dealt with the economy. Of those 79, Senator Faulkner asked three—three questions on the economy. Yet he stands up in this chamber, gives himself a glowing character reference and glosses up his character as a man who would never slur anyone outside this chamber. But who hissed, Senator Ray? Who hissed? That is the question that has to be asked. The next thing we know, Senator Faulkner will be getting a call from the Women's Weekly. That is how much he glossed up his—
Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I knew that would get you back. That is how much Senator Faulkner has glossed up his own character. The point is, this has reached the end. It has now become a complete irrelevancy.
—You are a lying mongrel if that is what you are alleging.
—Order! Senator Ray—
—Point of order, Madam Deputy President—
—I am about to ask Senator Ray to withdraw the unparliamentary language.
—With respect, you should stand.
—I am about to ask him to withdraw. I am also about to ask Senator McGauran not to reflect upon members of either house.
—I withdraw. I point out that Senator Parer, I thought, accepted that those events did not occur.
—You only had to withdraw; you were not given leave to make a statement.
—That is right. Do you want to get up and have a say for once? Just pay your speeding tickets and get on with it.
—Order! Senator Ray!

—The point is that, on any analysis of question time today, this has reached an irrelevancy because Senator Parer has made his disclosures to the Prime Minister and to cabinet. He has made his disclosures to the Senate. He has even taken it a step further and completely disinvested himself. So we have come to the end of the road of the Parer attack, just as we did with the Natural Heritage Trust.

speech.para: But who is leading these two attacks? Of course, it is Senator Faulkner—the same man who glossed up his character today but who, in fact, owes this chamber an apology and owes the Baillieu family an apology for his attack on the Baillieu family. He said, backed up by Senator Ray, regarding the Woodhouse Pastoral Co. listed at 360 Collins Street, that Maurice Howard Lawrence Baillieu and Richard Percy Clive Baillieu benefited from the government's Natural Heritage Trust—benefited in some way directly by the government's handout.

The fact is, both these men have been dead—one for 37 years, and I believe the other one for around 50 years. That scandalous attack warrants an apology in this chamber, if we are at all to believe that Senator Faulkner has a character that would never slur anyone inside or outside this chamber—particularly outside this chamber.

Also, Senator Faulkner, who glossed up his character today, the man who said that he would never slur anyone inside or outside this chamber, the man that has the thick skin, is the same man who has been defending Senator Bolkus who was censured by the Senate—the first time an opposition frontbencher has been censured for some 30 years—with the support of the Democrats, with the support of the Greens and with the support of Senator Harradine. The whole chamber, other than the Labor opposition, supported this censure against Senator Bolkus. Why? Because he was caught on film releasing quite sensitive court documents which has prejudiced the government's case and chase against Skase. If that does not warrant a sacking from the frontbench, then obviously no-one on that frontbench will go for any reason at all.
Just to reiterate, the point of the matter is that this has run its course. It has all the look of the Natural Heritage Trust, where apologies will have to be made at the end of the day.

talk.start.para: —This is a case in which there is a clear breach of public duty by a minister, and where his public duty has been confused with his private gain. There is no question about that. The Prime Minister set down the test. It is in his guidelines. He called them at the time, I might say, his `code'; he now calls them his `guidelines'. There is a reason for that, and I will come to it in a minute.

speech.para: Today in question time I asked Senator Parer about three decisions he made as a minister which affected the benefit of the coal industry. This is a minister who, when he made those decisions, had private investments in the coal industry. His defence was that they were generic, they affected the whole of the industry. Ergo, they affected his company too. If this is a question of justice being done and justice being seen to be done, the right thing being done or the right thing being seen to be done, his decisions—the three of them—affected his private fortune. There is no way in which that is not true.

talk.start.para: —That is what you are sore about; it is the politics of envy.

—You can shout and rant. It stands there like a pikestaff before your eyes as a fact. It is a fact that that means he is in direct, flagrant contravention of the Prime Minister's own guidelines. What is the response of the Prime Minister in these circumstances? To reinterpret the guidelines. Remember when the Prime Minister told us these were codes? Now we have caught a minister, they are guidelines. They are not codes—you do not have to abide by them. Now they are just guides to action.

speech.para: I want to know from this minister why he will not answer my question. Three separate times he made decisions which affected his private fortune as a minister for this industry. Why won't he answer? In the second part of my question, I asked him, `Do you deny that Jellinbah coalmine, in which you and your family have a lucrative interest, has derived any benefit from the program at all?' Cast your mind back. When this government came to office—and we had some questions about this today, laughable though they were—it embarked in its 1996-97 budget on the biggest cost-cutting spree ever. It cut every program across the board. It kept this program—the coal export facilitation program, the CEF program—that benefited this minister.
I asked this minister if his company benefited from that program. Did he answer the question? No, he did not. If the program does not work to benefit coalmining companies, why keep the program?
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That is exactly right. Why keep it when you are cutting everything else? Why, when you have got a scorched earth policy about budget cuts, do you keep this particular program if it does not benefit that particular company? That is what this minister now has to answer.

speech.para: He has argued up until now there has been no conflict. `You have not caught me,' is his argument. This is the thief's argument. `I may have robbed the building, I may have the jewels in my bag, I may have got them to the fence; but I am innocent because you haven't caught me and you haven't proved that I did it.' That is the argument being put here—the thief's argument. There is now a clear case of there being three occasions on which he has made decisions on which his—

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President—
—Of course you want to shut me up.
—Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: I just want to clarify whether Senator Cook is inferring that Senator Parer is a thief, because if he is he should withdraw it.

—Order, Senator Alston! Senator Cook, you may wish to clarify to whom you were referring and, if you were referring to the minister as such, then it is out of order. If you were not, if you were making a generic comment, it is not out of order.

—I said that he employed the thief's defence: `I stole. I've got the goods. I sold them. But you haven't caught me and, until you catch me, I am not guilty.' That is what I said and I am happy to repeat it.

speech.para: There is a question here, front and centre, for this government. We now know that the Prime Minister has double standards. He defines promises and core promises. If you do not understand the difference between a promise and a core promise, bad luck—you lose. We now know that he has a code and a guideline. If you do not understand that guidelines are not meant to be kept, then you lose. We now understand that, if you have investments in your own industry, that is not an offence. Even if it is seen to conflict, the fact that you then have to prove that it does means it is not an offence. We now know that, if your family benefits, as long as they are adults and not children, that is not an offence either, although it is very directly front and centre in conflict with the Prime Minister's own guidelines.

We have here a Prime Minister who redefines the issue as he goes along to protect his ministers. This is a weak Prime Minister. This is someone without the guts to defend the position he puts publicly. This is a Prime Minister with no leadership power or strength. If he had any, he would enforce his own standards. (Time expired)
Senator Ferguson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Ferguson, interjections are disorderly at the best of times, and they are even more so when you are not in your seat. So I would ask for some silence, please.

—I was interested to listen to Senator Cook's explanation of the point of order that Senator Calvert took on what Senator Cook, I am sure, said about Senator Parer. We will check Hansard very carefully tomorrow to see just what Senator Cook did call Senator Parer. I think the Senate needs to be reminded that, on 7 April 1989, Senator Cook, the then Minister for Resources, was actually censured by this Senate for improper alteration of the Hansard record of an answer that he gave in response to a question without notice. We know Senator Cook's track record, so it will be interesting to see the Hansard tomorrow.

speech.para: What is even more interesting is that, throughout this debate that we now have had raging over a number of days, the opposition cannot bear to look at their own record. They have pursued one minister in the Liberal government, the coalition government, after the other. But, when we look at what their track record is, I do not recall Senator Cook, Senator Faulkner, Senator Ray or anyone else on that side talking about Alan Griffiths owning a sandwich shop while he was Minister for Industry. I do not recall them complaining about Graham Richardson being a director of 2HD while he was Minister for Communications and not declaring his interests. I do not recall them complaining about Senator Richardson using his position as a minister to try to influence the President of the Marshall Islands on behalf of his cousin, Greg Symons—there was not a whimper.

I do not recall the opposition complaining about John Dawkins's mother owning Bell shares while Holmes a Court was trying to take over BHP. I do not recall them complaining about Bob Hawke being a personal friend of Sir Peter Abeles when Abeles was trying to crush the pilots union in 1989. I do not recall them complaining about Bob Hawke using his position as PM to collect $1 million from four Western Australian business leaders, otherwise known as the `gold tax' lunch, as Senator Cook would well remember.

They did not complain either about Gareth Evans. While foreign minister he wrote the blue book on diplomacy—that would be a first, wouldn't it?—using ANU academics without acknowledging their contributions. That is otherwise known as plagiarism, of course. Paul Keating and Gareth Evans used their positions to attack Justice Marks in the royal commission on the Easton affair. The list goes on. I would need half an hour to go through this—I have got pages and pages of it. But not a whimper came out of the Labor opposition, the then government, saying, `You've got to go. You've disgraced the government. You've got to go.'

Yet opposition senators come in day after day attacking Senator Parer, who has not made one, single, solitary decision in conflict with his interests. These weak-kneed little people over the other side keep trying to bring successful people down. Why don't they concentrate on the main issues? Senator McGauran mentioned earlier, for example, that the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, had asked three questions without notice on unemployment in 12 months. This amounted to three questions in 85 sitting days—and there would have been more sitting days than that now—but no questions on jobs since August 1997. Senator Cook, who is in the chamber at the moment and who supposedly represents the shadow Treasurer in the Senate and is the shadow minister for trade, has asked only two questions. Why don't they concentrate on the main issues?

At the end of 1997, the Labor Party had asked a mere 21 questions without notice on unemployment out of a total of 583 questions. That represents four per cent of the total questions asked, but certainly no direct questions on unemployment have been asked in 1998. It is just absolutely absurd. They do not want to focus on the main issue. At the end of last year, Labor had asked a lowly 79 questions out of 583 on the economy. Why? Because they do not like the message on the economy. They do not like all the good economic indicators. They want to muckrake. They want to go through the whole scaremongering exercise. They have just concentrated on diversions, muckraking and smears in the whole of 1997 and nothing at all has changed in 1998. They are not inter ested in the real issues. They have not released one single, solitary policy in over two years in opposition. Where are the policies? Where is your health policy? Where is your tax policy? Where is your trade policy? Not one has been released.

—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: A call to label genetically engineered foods and food products.
We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:
a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production: irradiated foods (internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt-reduced; free-range; vitamin-enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

talk.start.para: Senator Stott Despoja(from 1,180 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

This petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales notes with concern the impact of the policy of charging entry fees—often necessitating the sale of the family home—for people needing nursing home care. Furthermore, the petitioners note with concern the impact of the policy of charging residents of aged care facilities an extra daily fee which provides no additional benefit to the resident and is nothing more than a disguised tax.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate act to ensure that nursing home care is equally available to all who need it and further that the family home is exempted from any asset test relating to payment for such care.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

(b) increase the costs of scholarships resulting in fewer part-scholarships or part-time scholarships of less value; and

talk.start.para: Senator Stott Despoja(from 38 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This petition from the undersigned shows that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia. We have a responsibility to future and present generations to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:
(1) immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

(2) ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old-growth forests, rainforests and habitats of endangered species;
(3) facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed-species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands;
(4) maximise use of readily-available plantation timber for industry needs, using progressive minimal-waste processing methods, and where possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;
(5) support incentives for nationwide composting and soil remineralisation;
(6) encourage environmental education tourism with respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage; and
(7) utilise expertise and resources from the military sector to help implement these tree planting solutions.

talk.start.para: Senator Woodley(from 25 citizens)

The Petition of the undersigned requests that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this country are treated justly and fairly. It is in the interest of all to build this nation in a spirit of reconciliation and cooperation with Australians of diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds.

We call on you to ensure that regional agreements with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are pursued in good faith, so as to determine their rights to their land in a spirit of reconciliation.

The co-existence of Native Title and Pastoral Leases on Crown Land is supported by legal principle and historic fact, upheld by the High Court. The people and Governments of Australia have a moral responsibility to give this fact real and just effect.
We call on members of the Senate to ensure that legislation regarding Native Title
(i) complies with internationally recognised principles of non-discrimination; and
(ii) promotes Reconciliation with Australia's first peoples.

The humble petition of the Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
That we:
affirm the pre-eminence of parents' rights to give wise guidance and direction to their children
affirm the primary and inalienable rights and responsibility of parents to nurture, educate, control and discipline their children

oppose the autonomous rights given to children by Articles 12 to 16 of the Convention, which may allow them access to morally harmful material and people (with no adequate protec tion) and which undermine parental rights and disrupt proper family life.
