This provision, if it were to get through, would act as a disincentive to employment in the longer term. If the government were serious about helping businesses to grow, helping businesses to employ and helping businesses to export, then they would drop this legislation rather than cynically use it as a means of achieving a double dissolution.

So why 15? Why not 12? Why not 10? Why not five? There is no rhyme, no reason, no justification, other than that tenuous link put up by the minister, which completely destroys itself. What we are seeing with this piece of legislation is a piece of legislation designed to destroy the fundamental rights of people in the work force.

The government are saying, `This really doesn't have any effect on existing employees.' But as Senator Murray pointed out, and rightly so, many of these small businesses have a very high turnover of staff, so what we will see in a very short space of time is this legislation taking effect a lot quicker than even the government would be prepared to admit. We would have people exposed a lot earlier than even the government would be prepared to concede.

What we see in the legislation is fundamentally a denial of justice to a certain class of employees. It certainly could not be described as being fair to the employees who work for small businesses wherein there are 15 or fewer employed. The employees are not protected from the harsh and oppressive employers—and there are harsh and oppressive employers out there in the real world. They cannot all be painted as being Latter-day Saints. Certainly, many of them are quite disgusting in the way they treat their employees.
If one looks further at the second reading speech, one would see again the cynicism that exists in the government's approach. The minister said:

The new system is more balanced and fair to both employers and employees. It is less legalistic and costly, with an emphasis on conciliation. Employers are protected from frivolous and malicious claims—

This is just a load of nonsense. What we are talking about here are the fundamental basic rights of these people. The minister said in his second reading speech that, if this legislation is passed, the employers will be protected from frivolous and malicious claims and will thereby, in some way, benefit. What we are going to see is the denial of people's rights, and people in this nation have got to make up their minds what comes first—people's rights or employers being protected from frivolous and malicious claims.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 6.50 p.m., we move to the consideration of government documents.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish to take note of this report because it is an encouraging report for several reasons. It describes in detail the excellent year the organisation has had. It provides evidence of how good marketing and clever export strategies can significantly boost the fortunes of the rural sector, and it represents the fulfil ment of another election commitment—that is, the complete restructure of the Wheat Board.

This government has been and is committed to the reform of all key rural industries. It is committed to extracting government from activities that industries can and should do for themselves, and it is committed to putting the people with the most practical knowledge and experience back in charge of their own industries.

Under the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Anderson, we have overhauled the sugar industry, the marketing of red meat and the marketing of wool, and now the government has substantially met the expectations of the industry by restructuring the Australian Wheat Board, which is the country's major national and international grain marketing organisation. The reforms are certainly starting to bear results.

The board is Australia's fifth largest exporter, selling and marketing grain on behalf of Australia's 40,000 wheat growers. It is now in the process of moving from a statutory authority to a grower owned and controlled organisation and, in partnership with the growers, the government has assisted this change. Full privatisation is scheduled for 1 July 1999 and some of the preparation for this is described in this 1996-97 report.

On 1 July 1999, the Australian Wheat Board will become a stand-alone corporation—Australian owned and operated under the Australian Corporations Law and run by its own elected board with a capital base of around $550 million. The only real area of government involvement is the board's current work—that is, the provision of underwriting on the borrowings of wheat growers to fund advance payments to growers, which will cease in 1999, and the single desk export powers on wheat, which will remain.

In 1999-2000, the Australian government will review this single desk structure as part of its national competition policy. In connection with the finalisation of the package for the conversion of the AWB to a grower owned company from July 1999, I personally am very pleased that the Grains Council has unanimously endorsed the dual class share grower company to replace the AWB after that time. I am convinced that this is the best means to meet with the government's and industry's objectives for a self-reliant, fully commercialised marketing structure under grower ownership and control.

The government will now consider the post-1999 package and legislation, and will take account of the matters put forward by the Grains Council for inclusion in the memorandum and articles of association of the new company to strengthen pooling arrangements and grower control. I am aware and note that the Australian Stock Exchange has confirmed that the grower control arrangements for the company could be retained if the company were listed, so long as the company is primarily involved in grain trading, and growers would have the controlling say in whether or not the company does continue as a grain trader.

Some of the board's key achievements during 1996-97 form part of the report's introduction. They include a range of successes—namely, the increase in sales revenue of seven per cent to an all-time high of $4.7 billion; the increase in export sales volumes by over 40 per cent to 19 million tonnes, the highest level ever achieved; and an enormous increase in export sales, which were achieved to Iran, Pakistan, Egypt, Iraq, Turkey, Indonesia and Yemen. This is a fine organisation. It is doing the right thing by its growers and by the Australian government. In the interest of all Australians, it should be congratulated on the work that it has carried out over the last 12 months.

talk.start.para: —I note in the annual report that, in the financial year ended June 1997, the sales revenue of the Australian Wheat Board was $4.682 billion. Importantly, the holdings of the wheat industry fund at the end of that year were $444 million, which involved $70 million in levies on the wheat industry. Of course, we have heard about the restructuring of the wheat industry from Senator Sandy Macdonald, which was one of the key items on Mr Anderson's agenda back when he was appointed Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in March 1996.

speech.para: This process was actually kicked off by the former government, but he was charged with the responsibility of carrying the reform through. However, I have to say that, under Mr Anderson's management, the process of reform has been an extremely tortuous one. The reason is simple—that is, a lack of leadership on his part. I hasten to add that the Australian Wheat Board reform is not the only area in the primary industry portfolio that has suffered from this problem. The reform of the meat industry, the reform of the export meat inspection service and the development of an effective management plan to deal with Ovine Johnes disease have also suffered badly from a lack of direction from the minister.

The debate within the industry over the future of the Australian Wheat Board has been a difficult one, and that is understandable. The industry is dealing with its future and is quite rightly concerned that the structure which is finally agreed to ensures that the future is sustainable. The biggest problem has not been the process of debate within the industry; it has been the fact that no-one really knows the detail of what the government will finally propose to parliament.

The legislative framework to implement this process was split into two bills. This parliament was asked to vote on, and the industry was asked to endorse, a privatised Australian Wheat Board with only half of the information on the table. But, despite the failing of the minister in the process, we are now at a point where the industry broadly supports a model which is acceptable to the government. There are still some concerns in Western Australia, as I understand it. The Labor Party will certainly look to the view of the industry when determining its position on the second tranche of legislation when that finally appears. I assume that industry support is subject to the detail contained in this second piece of legislation.

The industry support, however, is also subject to four key conditions. They are: that the articles of the Australian Wheat Board post-1999 contain a limit on the capital of the trading subsidiary of $100 million; that the articles of the Australian Wheat Board post- 1999 include three external directors elected by A-class shareholders to the board of the pool company subsidiary; that the taxation expectations of the Grains Council of Australia are granted in full by the government—and that has been a fundamental issue to the industry all the way along; and, that the preservation of cooperation principles in the pooling company are maintained.

I understand the Grains Council has advised the minister that support for the model as is currently presented will be withdrawn by all states if any of the above conditions are not met by the government. This is a matter now well and truly back on Mr Anderson's ministerial desk. It is his responsibility to address the above conditions required by the industry, and it is a matter for him to ensure that the second bill accurately reflects what the Australian industry rightly expects.

As with a number of other key policy areas, the minister has attempted to take a back seat on this important reform. He has argued that rural industries must determine their own destinies and, therefore, he should not involve himself. There is a big difference between interfering and leading. This minister, as well as a number of other ministers in this government, has a key role to play in the development of key rural industries such as wheat. It is about time he started exercising his responsibility.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I would like to take note of this report regarding the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and the report that has been submitted by the Higher Education Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. At the outset, let me say that it is nice to see some reports coming from NBEET—a fine body, but one that has effectively been disbanded under the coalition government.

I wonder what is in fact happening with the legislation that seeks to disband the work of NBEET. I know that we have never dealt with it in this place, although their funding has been more or less decimated. I think it will be a great shame when we see the abolition of a body that provides essential cross-sectoral advice to the government and other bodies on such important education, employment and training matters.

This particular report is in relation to quality implementation and reporting structures and, essentially, deals with the qualitative monitoring of the Australian tertiary sector, an issue on which, of course, the Australian Democrats have long been vocal. I note that this report makes a number of recommendations, including that there should be three-yearly reviews of institutional quality and that they take the form of desk audits of material provided by institutions for the profiles discussion and additional material that is required.

This is, I think, an important and good recommendation that the Democrats would be pleased to support. But, again, we throw open the question to the government as to whether or not it has had feedback recently on this year's and last year's profiles process from tertiary institutions around the country. From my own discussions with some administrators and vice-chancellors, there have been some concerns in the process of obtaining profiles information over the last year.

The second recommendation—that the council, during this year, continue to liaise with the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee as well as the department in relation to sector-wide performance indicators—is one that I think we would support also. There is, however, an addition or recommendation that I would make on behalf of my party and that is that student and academic unions are involved in this process of consultation. There is little point in trying to shore up quality in the sector unless all those perspectives are represented and reflected.

I note also that this report looks into the quality of the higher education sector in Australia, as well as the health of the sector. In an attempt to gauge the health of the sector and the appropriate reporting devices, it looks into a recent history of the quality of the sector. I have to say that the recent history of higher education in this country has been marked by rapid change, massive upheaval and, of course, incredible funding cuts, the nature of which I do not think has been seen in this country before in relation to higher education specifically.

We have seen an increase in fees and charges and the introduction of a three-tier HECS system. We have seen a reduction of the threshold at which graduates begin to repay their HECS debts. We have seen a failure by government to actually meet the need for increased wages for the academics and general staff among university institutions. We have seen, effectively, a $1.7 billion cut to operating grants which, I have no doubt, has affected the performance of institutions. Of course it has also affected the quality of education provided by those institutions, not, I might add, through any fault of their own, but just through the sheer difficulty, almost impossibility, of providing many services in departments and on campuses, especially those regional campuses, when you are starved for funds.

We have seen in recent history a deregulation of both the postgraduate and the undergraduate sector, and I would like to put on record that, according to recent DEETYA figures, out of the 1,300 full fee places, only 794 have been taken up. That represents 61 per cent, significantly less than expected. Again, that has not only been an economic disaster for institutions but it has also had, I believe, adverse impacts on the access and equity of our higher education institutions.

I note that these issues are topical. On 1 April the National Tertiary Education Union and the National Union of Students will be hosting another national day of action, certainly in the lead-up to a federal election, to send a message to this government that you just cannot keep cutting funds for education. You cannot treat education as a cost as opposed to an investment and expect that the institutions will provide the quality that is expected through reports such as this, let alone an enlightened, skilled and democratic society.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Jacinta Collins)

talk.start.para: — Consideration of government documents having concluded, I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I know it is months until we have Australia's greatest horse race, the Melbourne Cup. But there is another political race well under way, and the winner's prize is going to be equally glittering. Those taking part in the race are the aging thoroughbreds of the Australian Labor Party, and they are running in the Hypocrites Cup. These old stallions, the old bush brumbies, and a couple of fillies on the track as well, are lining up for the Telstra prize to be awarded to the most effective hypocrite on the field. They are still bunched up; they are each looking for a winning opening, but their collective equine mantra remains the same: privatisation is good when you are in government but bad when you are in opposition.

speech.para: The stakes in this particular steeplechase are prized and the rewards for the first past the post are highly sought after. We are offering the prize—the opportunity to share in the ownership of our number one company Telstra. We want to give hundreds of Australian men and women a chance at that prize—to invest in our nation and to profit from that investment. Our plan has another benefit for all Australians. It is an historic opportunity to reduce government debt; to use the dollars from the sale to repay the massive debts left by one of the noisiest stallions on the field—the one from the West who has been spelling for a little too long in the front paddock.

The first partial sale of Telstra was so popular that even a couple of runners bought in—an Irish brumby and one of the more mature fillies, I am told. In fact, more than 14 per cent of Australian adults made a direct investment in the first sale of Telstra shares. Many more invested indirectly through superannuation funds, trusts and managed investments. In November 1997, Telstra shares cost Australians $1.95 and they are now worth $3.94. That represents a 94 per cent profit—not a bad return in less than 12 months.

At least 90 per cent of the people who bought into Telstra still own those shares. In fact, 92 per cent of Telstra employees seized the opportunity last year to buy shares in their own company. Without doubt, many of them were members of the trade union that covers the communications industry. What a wise decision those people made.

The coalition is helping to create a nation of shareholders. We now live in a country where share ownership has soared to a record 40 per cent. More than 5½ million adult Australians now have a direct stake in the domestic share market. What an achievement. Unlike Labor, we are not selling off the farm overseas; we are selling it back to Australian companies, Australian families and Australian investment funds.

The initial one-third sale of Telstra was not only good for Australian shareholders, but the sale also financed the magnificent $1 billion Natural Heritage Trust fund—the largest environmental rescue package in Australia's history—and the $250 million regional telecommunications infrastructure fund to help regional Australia. Australia now has an increasingly competitive telecommunications industry, with better service and lower prices. People with families living in states distant from their homes can now make phone calls at greatly reduced prices. I was delighted that on St Patrick's Day Telstra was able to offer special rates to people to phone their families overseas. That was a very wise investment.

The Prime Minister has made it very clear that not only will the privatisation of the remainder of Telstra help people who choose to buy into it, but it will also yield a social bonus, the details of which are yet to be announced.

Despite the success of the initial float, those running in the Hypocrites Cup cannot tell us why they oppose the further sale of Telstra. One of the fillies was heard to say—but, importantly, it was said before this race got under way and before she was stabled with the other runners—that it is pretty hard for them to sound credible on Telstra and difficult for them to carve out a positive reason for people to vote for them. She said that when she was in a smaller stable, before she joined the bunch which is on the field now.

I am not much of a punter myself but my money for the winner of the Hypocrites Cup is on the bulky stallion from the West, who was heard to say—again before the race even started—that he would cancel the whole darned thing and take the Telstra Prize back from the entire Australian community—he's got some chance of doing that! We know that the real winner in the Telstra race is the Australian community—the thousands of men and women who will again invest in our number one company and justifiably reap the rewards due to them from that decision.

talk.start.para: —I am glad that the previous speaker wanted to talk about the Telstra Prize and things going to regional Australia, because it is quite apparent that this government does not give a toss. Some senior ministers in this government do not give a toss. I have before me a newsletter from the Hon. John Fahey, Minister for Finance and Administration. The newsletter is headed `Airport News for Macarthur from your local Federal Member John Fahey MP March 98'. Mr Fahey wants to talk about the airport. That is fine, as Macarthur is an electorate on which the airport may have some impact.

speech.para: I remind people that this man was the former Premier of New South Wales so, hopefully, when he is talking about these things he is conscious of what impact what he is suggesting will have on rural New South Wales. In the third paragraph on the first page of the newsletter he says:
Before the election, I promised that no decision would be made about Sydney's second airport before a full EIS had been undertaken.

I think that is a wise decision, but he says `I promised'—was he the person who promised? This would certainly give a pretty clear indication of how much power this gentleman has, and it is obviously quite significant. On page 2 of this four-page newsletter he talks about the different options. He says:
I would need to be satisfied that for Option A to proceed as an overflow airport for Kingsford Smith Airport—the existing airport at Bankstown could not instead perform a similar function.
The alarm bells start to ring! What does this really mean? What is the potential impact of this upon rural Australia? On page 3 he comments:
In particular, I want know more about the `do nothing option' at Kingsford Smith Airport . . .

This is beginning to sound a little bit concerning for rural people. I might add that Macarthur is semi-rural in its geographical location, but it does not have any airports. Mr Fahey really lets the cat out of the bag on page 4. The heading says, `Does Sydney need a second airport?' The newsletter continues:

para.inline: Is Sydney Airport being used as efficiently as possible?

speech.para: Government is constantly told that Sydney Airport will reach saturation point by the year 2006 and a second airport must be operational to meet travellers' demands.

para.inline: According to figures I have seen, the fastest growing type of aircraft movement at Sydney Airport is for small aircraft on regional flights not the larger domestic or international jets.

speech.para: That is all very fun and games if you want to play with statistics, which this gentleman has done. He then has a table setting out year, international flights, domestic flights, regional flights, non-scheduled flights and total. In 1990-91, international flights in and out of KSA were 32,000, which was 17 per cent of movements. Domestic movements were 85,000, which was 44 per cent of movements. Regional movements were 49,000, which was 25 per cent of movements. Non-scheduled movements were 26,500, which was 14 per cent of movements. That gave a total of 192,500 movements.

In 1996-97, international flights were 43,000 movements, which was 16 per cent of movements. He is going to tell us that there has been a reduction in the number of movements percentage wise. There certainly has not been a reduction in the number of movements per se. It has gone up by 11,000. Domestic movements increased to 108,000, which was 40 per cent of the flight movements. Regional movements, yes, increased to 94,000, which was 35 per cent. Non-scheduled movements decreased to 24,600, which was nine per cent. That gave a total of 269,600 movements. The minister says:

Of about 270,000 aircraft movements at Sydney Airport in 1996/97, 44% were regional and non-scheduled flights, such as, small planes from other places in NSW, charter flights, private planes, military and training flights, etc.

If regional and other smaller flights such as these can be diverted to another airport, perhaps Bankstown, it may be that a second airport is not required for decades to come—it's a possibility that would require detailed investigation.

This is from a man who was a former Premier of New South Wales, the state affected. He is right to note the increase in regional movements, because that indicates very clearly that the regional people of New South Wales want to get access to KSA. They want to get access to Sydney. It is important to them for a number of reasons. But this man, who is one of the most senior members of the current government in the cabinet, is saying that people in rural New South Wales ought to be put somewhere else.

If you read the speeches that I have made previously when debating the increase in airport charges, landing charges and movement charges, at Kingsford Smith airport and put them together with this, it becomes a very ominous situation. This is a government that could not give a toss about rural New South Wales. The Senate has exposed this, and is enabling people to have a say by conducting a Senate inquiry into the charging of fees.

The minister for finance must be very senior and very powerful because the trials and tribulations, and any problems that might have existed when we were in government, or any things that might have been done not quite in the way the government of today thinks they should have been done, have been heaped upon the head of the Kim Beazley who was then the Minister for Finance. So we know very clearly from the government's attitude to former ministers for finance that they are very senior and very powerful. What does this tell us? What message does this send to regional and rural New South Wales? It sends the message: I don't care; I couldn't give a toss.

I notice that two of the three government senators in the chamber at present are from New South Wales and one is from a regional area. I hope he very severely takes the Minister for Finance and Administration aside and informs him of the needs of rural and regional New South Wales. It is the most populous state in the country. It has got significant industries outside of the metropolitan area.

What does this government, obviously through its senior minister, plan to do? This press release is the first indication of what they are planning to do. It is a follow-on from them allowing, or not stopping, the FAC to up the landing charges and fees at Kingsford Smith airport. This is another turn in the ratchet to tighten the thumbscrews, to get regional and rural commuters out of Kingsford Smith airport, and I ask you: to where? I do not know to where. They are obviously talking about Bankstown. Isn't it amazing that Bankstown is not anywhere near a Liberal held seat, so the people of Blaxland will have to suffer this fate of additional aircraft movements, and much larger aircraft will be forced in and out of Bankstown than is actually able to go there now.

This is a government that obviously does not care. People from the bush do not want to be landed an hour or two away from the centre of the city. Their business is in the centre of the city or with other domestic flights connecting elsewhere. I could not believe this press release when I saw it. It is vitally important that the people of rural and regional New South Wales know that this senior minister, the Minister for Finance and Administration, a cabinet minister, is saying that this is what he thinks should be happening.

We know from the government's previous utterances that finance ministers are very powerful. If they are going to tell me that Mr Fahey is not powerful, then they have to retract all the things they have said about the Leader of the Opposition. They cannot have it both ways. They cannot walk both sides of the street at the one time. If they do, they will get run over by the bus that will come up the middle, and the bus will be the people of rural and regional New South Wales as they suddenly discover that they are going to have their access to Sydney Kingsford Smith airport and other trade and transport routes blocked and stopped.

I think it is high time this government actually admitted what they are planning to do and gave some guarantees to the people of rural and regional New South Wales as to how they are going to protect their access to Sydney and their access and ability to utilise commuter and regional aircraft.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak tonight on an important matter, and that is the situation faced by Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families. Senators would no doubt be aware of recent media reports of the Vietnam veterans health study which highlighted yet again the extremely poor health not only of our Vietnam veterans but also of their families. It is bad enough that study after study has been called into the health of veterans. Clearly, not enough has been done to address these problems. The situation must be acted upon now if continuing high death rates and levels of ill health are to be addressed amongst Vietnam veterans and their children.

speech.para: These people are not just statistics. There were some fairly daunting and overwhelming statistics included in the media reports in relation to this study. It is important to remember that they are not just statistics but real men and women and their families. The recent media coverage highlighted some families, particularly those involving birth defects in children of Vietnam veterans. One of the other things that came out of the study was the high rate of suicide not just amongst veterans but also amongst their children. It means that not just one generation of Australians is paying the price for fighting this unfortunate war in someone else's country but two. If we do not act now that tragedy will continue to spread further into the future.

As the world recently held its breath at the prospect of biological warfare rising up in the Middle East, the fact is that over two decades ago some of our fittest, brightest young Australians were sent to fight in a war which featured widespread use of chemicals, the effects of which were clearly not understood at the time but have clearly shown their effects ever since. This latest report backs up what most people have known to be correct for many years.
I refer to a speech made by one of my Queensland predecessors former Senator Michael Macklin in August 1981. He stated:

I appeal to the Minister and to the Government to . . . wait no longer to assist those veterans; to accept now that we have sufficient evidence that they are being affected by the things that occurred in Vietnam.

These calls have not just been made by the Democrats but by many people in the broader veterans community and health and welfare groups for many years. Whilst government has acted to some extent over time—I am not wishing to imply that nothing at all has been done—it is clear that not enough has been done and the problems and situations faced by Vietnam veterans and their families are not addressed seriously enough. The delays and inadequacy of action have done nothing but compound the anger and suffering of veterans and exacerbated the problems they and their children suffer.
I think it is important to put on the record the comments on the latest report by Mr Tim McCombe, the President of the Vietnam Veterans Federation of Australia. He stated:

This is no surprise to us. We have been warning governments and an unsympathetic Department of Veterans' Affairs about this for years. The findings are even worse when you consider that those sent to Vietnam were very carefully selected for physical and mental health. So high were the standards that half of all those called up for national service were rejected on medical or psychological grounds.

It is not average members of the community who are now suffering these problems but amongst the fittest and healthiest of the Australian community at that time that are suffering health problems that are vastly out of proportion to those suffered by the wider Australian community. Surely there is no-one now who persists in arguing against the effect of agent orange and other chemicals on Vietnam veterans during that war or the complex and major psychological problems that have beset veterans not only in Australia but also in other countries which engaged in that conflict.

In responding to the leaks of the latest health study, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Scott, is reported as saying, `If the results are confirmed the government will consider whether additional measures are required.' I would suggest that if these results are confirmed—and, as I have said already, it does not seem that there is terribly much doubt about the general extent of them—then the minister does not need to do much more considering before acting on this problem. The Democrats believe that the time for another round of reconfirmation, re-studying and re-examination of the problems has well and truly passed. It is time for the minister and the government to act.

These latest findings are tragic for several reasons, not least because more could have been and should have been done to offset the problems experienced by Vietnam veterans, their children and their families over many years. I wonder what else has to be confirmed. The study tells us that children of veterans have spina bifida and other birth defects at levels up to 10 times that of the rest of the community as well as much higher than average suicide rates. The study found that for veterans the rate of breast cancer is up to 10 times above the average, colon cancer is three times higher, leukaemia is three times higher and other cancers such as prostrate and neck cancer are up to three times higher and depressive orders are from 20 to 200 per cent higher.

Surely this is enough to act on. Maybe re-examining the situation might get some slight variations in some of those figures but surely no-one can deny that they are well above the average for the Australian community and they are problems that must be addressed now. The results of this study may have major implications for veterans seeking legal recourse for the damage done to them and their families.

Some Australians might be surprised at just how bad the situation is, but it is difficult to believe the reported comments from officials of the Department of Veterans' Affairs who say that they are shocked at the findings. Maybe the extent of some of these specific conditions were a bit of a surprise in specific circumstances but surely the overall incidence of these various conditions could not have been a surprise to anybody, let alone people in the department who have surely been following the situation of Vietnam veterans for many years. I again quote Mr McCombe where he stated:

The veteran community for good reason lacks confidence and trust in the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The Department has over the years proved devious and unsympathetic. It has certainly not delivered the generosity of care and compensation promised so often to veterans by government.

This is not a new message. I draw the attention of senators to a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment in 1982 that looked into pesticides and the health of Australian Vietnam veterans. Among many other things, it detailed widespread allegations of Vietnam veterans complaining about the treatment they got from the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

I am not wanting to sheet home all the blame to the department or its workers. I recognise that they have a difficult job and are dealing with difficult situations. Clearly, however, a big problem still exists. It is obvious that not enough has been done to address the concerns and the feelings of the Vietnam veterans community.

I also point to another speech by former Democrat Senator Macklin in 1985 where he highlighted some years later, ongoing problems and concerns amongst veterans about the type of treatment they received from the department and the adequacy and accuracy of the information they had received. That is an ongoing problem judging by a recent report of the Ombudsman in terms of the accuracy of phone advice provided by many departments, not just Veterans' Affairs. Again, it points to the need for more action in this regard.

Surely the department has seen enough now to know that more action needs to be taken. It has seen the other findings, read all the other studies from both here and overseas, is aware of the widespread anecdotal evidence of the effects on individual veterans and their families across the community. Again, these stories and these messages go back at least two decades. To have that sort of message trying to go out for that length of time, and to still feel that they are not being heard, it is no wonder that the Vietnam veterans community cries out with such frustration.

The Democrats urge the minister to act now to review immediately the level and standards of health care being provided to veterans and their children. We urge the government to meet with Vietnam veterans, perhaps try and listen a little bit harder, and meet with their supporters and health workers as soon as possible to discuss the best way of addressing this urgent and terrible situation, and not to stint on any extra money that is needed to address the suffering of veterans and their families. I concur with the views, once again, of Mr McCombe, when he said, `We can only hope that the department and the government respond to this situation with some sympathy and some honesty.'

talk.start.para: —Friday, 13 March saw the start of the sixth Melbourne Food and Wine Festival, the premier food and wine event in Australia. With over 35 major events running from 13 March to 5 April, the festival is a fantastic showcase of the best of Victoria's culture and cuisine. But then Melbourne is, of course, the city of major events. Last year alone, major events contributed $650 million to the Victorian economy, and the tourism industry as a whole was worth $9.4 billion.

speech.para: Recently Melbourne has hosted the Australian Formula One Grand Prix, the Australian Masters at Huntingdale and the Australian Tennis Open. The arts are also well represented in Melbourne's calendar of events: the Melbourne Fashion Show, the Melbourne International Comedy Festival and the internationally acclaimed Melbourne Festival in October-November.

Melbourne really is the city of events and the Melbourne Food and Wine Festival is a marvellous example of why. Over three-quarters of a million people were exposed to the festival last year and the attendance grows annually, which is a tribute to the organisers and their innovation in regard to the range of activities available. In celebrating great food, world class Victorian wines, Melbourne's extensive range of restaurants and friendly people, the Melbourne Food and Wine Festival draws a large contingent of international and domestic visitors to Melbourne, reflecting the festival's international reputation. Eight hundred of the world's leading chefs gathered for the World Association of Cooks' Societies 28th World Congress from 15 to 19 March, while Master Class 1998 draws international authorities to compare knowledge and expertise across a wide range of fields.

Melbourne is the obvious place to host a festival celebrating food and wine. In its CBD alone there are over 300 restaurants representing 150 different ethnic cuisines, while the Yellow Pages listings of restaurants take up over 30 pages. There are 284 wineries in Victoria, more than in any other state, and most participate in the festival. Over 35,000 people in Victoria work in cafes or restaurants and a further 24,000 are employed in pubs and bars. So Melbourne really is the home to the ever increasing cafe and restaurant culture of Australian life, reflecting the dynamic multicultural nature of its people.

But Melbourne is the dynamic heart of a dynamic state, a fact reflected in the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry annual report on the states. The report shows Victoria's ranking moving from second place and knocking off—and rightly so—New South Wales from that position. In 1993, when VECCI started its annual report, Victoria was the worst performing state across a broad range of economic and financial indicators—hardly surprising considering the disastrous Cain-Kirner Labor governments the state had just endured. But, in the 1996-97 financial year, increasing retail sales and repayment of state debt pushed Victoria to second position amongst the states. Victoria was the only state to increase retail sales during the year and had the second lowest inflation rate in the country.

Furthermore, Victoria's economy now supports a higher proportion of small business owners than any other state. In Victoria, firms employing one to four people comprise 63.8 per cent of all enterprises. In addition, a further 28.7 per cent of enterprises employ between five and 19 people. These vital small businesses form 93.5 per cent of Victorian companies. Victoria also has the highest average profit per firm in Australia of $236,000. Our firms boast the highest average industry gross product per firm also.

Victoria's productivity performance was stronger than any state other than Western Australia and Victorian businesses now account for 21.7 per cent of national exports. Furthermore, the VECCI report considered that the Kennett government's policies had `secured the long-term viability of the Victorian economy' and noted that employment in Victoria had grown. Indeed it has! Just recently we heard that unemployment in Victoria had fallen to a record low in February of eight per cent, the lowest since December 1990, instead of the 12 and 13 per cent unemployment that Victoria suffered under the previous Labor government. The employment level falling to eight per cent is something that Victorians can be rightly proud of.

The vibrancy of Victoria's economic news is indicative of the feeling in my home state, and especially the city of Melbourne. Compared to 1990 and 1991 when, as a direct result of the recession we had to have and the financial irresponsibility of the then Labor Victorian and federal governments, there was a general feeling of depression in Victoria. Today, Melbourne pulsates with optimism and action and, as a result, Melbourne is becoming ever more attractive to visitors from overseas and interstate, and the increasing number of Victorians who prefer to holiday in their home state.

In the year ending March 1997, the Bureau of Tourism Research shows that more than 960,000 international visitors came to Melbourne, an increase of six per cent on the previous year. In 1997, 2.8 million interstate trips were made to Victoria—adding over $1.7 billion to the state's economy. The number of Victorians directly employed in the tourism sector has nearly doubled in four years to 8.2 per cent of the state's work force.

People visit Melbourne to do things: to attend festivals and to experience the arts, a new show or a sporting event. In fact, more than two million people attended either a meeting, convention or exhibition in Victoria last year, contributing $194 million to Victoria's economy. With a wonderful event like the Melbourne Food and Wine Festival—an event which showcases Melbourne's and Victoria's world-class produce, magnificent local wines and the excellence of the quality of life in Victoria—it is hardly surprising that so much international and national attention will be focused on Melbourne from 13 March to 5 April. I extend my best wishes to the organisers, the participants and the visitors for what is already proving to be a marvellous 1998 Melbourne Food and Wine Festival.

talk.start.para: —The Australian waterfront has long been the source of many stories about low hours, high pay, pilfering and general rorting of the system. We have heard of people signing on for work and then going home only to be paid for full shifts at huge hourly rates that make a mockery of wage restraint. But the report in Saturday's Daily Telegraph headed `Strip show shifts cargo' is nothing short of life imitating art. It revealed that a team of night shift waterfront workers in Western Australia achieved world's best practice container rates of about 30 an hour on one day about two months ago. The reason for this sudden uplift in productivity was that there was a strip show on at the local pub that some of the workers wanted to attend.

speech.para: I think it underscores the fact that the performance on our waterfront is, to put it bluntly, abysmal. Australia has one of the worst performance records in the world and this shocking record is costing the country dearly. A survey by the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce shows that Australian business is losing $1 billion a year because of the standard of our waterfront performance. One billion dollars a year is a lot of money.

talk.start.para: —Amazing; huge.

—It is not hard to see why, Senator Ellison, when you consider that Sydney's container terminals have managed to reach a crane rate of about 18 containers an hour for the first time ever. The New South Wales Labor government has whipped its mates in the stevedoring industry over the head with a feather over this performance. It entered into a secret agreement with the Maritime Union of Australia to minimise strikes. But such is the contempt this union has even for its Labor mates in New South Wales that this protocol has already been breached. It has left more than 4,000 containers stranded, a number of which are filled with flour which is aid for Syria and other countries in the Middle East. In this dispute the crane rate has dropped to 10 an hour.

speech.para: The situation in Sydney is that the wharfies are thumbing their noses even at their mates—as I say, Premier Bob Carr. They are demanding a guaranteed minimum, not average, wage of $75,000 per annum. They also want a base weekly wage of $712 for the calculation of superannuation entitlements. I ask rhetorically: just whom do these people think they are?

Mind you, Sydney is not the worst Australian port. Brisbane has yet to get to 18 containers an hour. Port Adelaide boasts the best performance in Australia with a paltry 21 containers an hour. It is a sad reflection of the level of our productivity when a level of 21 containers an hour is regarded as being something to be proud of. Just across the Tasman we have a rate of 25 containers an hour, while Thailand has 29 an hour and the Philippines has 30 an hour.

The wharfies are quite adamant that there is no productivity problem on this country's waterfront. They say you cannot compare Australia's performance with that of other countries because overseas ports overstate their performance. When you have this sort of attitude it is not hard to see why attempts by this government to speak reasonably with the wharfies have been unsuccessful.

The argument goes on to be contradicted. Wharfies have claimed that, if there is any problem with productivity, it is because the equipment is old. So on the one hand they are saying there is no problem and on the other hand they are saying there might be a problem. Their argument for the `might be' scenario does not really stack up as most of the equipment is new and state of the art.

Then there have been attempts to set a benchmark with the unions. The union will allow a benchmark only with an Australian port because, as you will remember from my earlier comments, those overseas ports actually overstate their productivity, according to the unions. So we cannot have any uncomfortable comparisons, can we?

So Australia is actually left with poor service and a service that is certainly not cheap. Container handling charges are a major contributor to our high waterfront charges, much greater than for any port in New Zealand or in Asia, and they are getting more expensive. Earlier this month charges for containers bound for Europe rose because of stevedoring costs. The new charges will add about $1 million to the cost of exports.

The shocking performance in container terminals is jeopardising this country's wellbeing, particularly as containerised cargo represents 60 per cent of the value of our imports and 30 per cent of the value of our exports. The unions who are the root cause of this problem are being paid a king's ransom.

Let us make no mistake about how well-off these wharfies are. These are not your average Australians battling to make a living. They are not your average Australians who agree to wage restraint in the interests of other workers. No, they are nothing less than bludgers who will go to astonishing lengths to exploit the system. And it is costing average Australians dearly. The costs they impose on the waterfront, of course, have to be passed on to the community.

The rorts are blatant. Take the wharfies with Patrick stevedoring in Newcastle. At present, they are working two days in five but are being paid for three days on which they do not turn up. If someone actually volunteers to come to work, he has to be paid time and a half. There are many practices that I would like to go into but I will not have time.

The New Zealand experience is very similar to that of Australia. In New Zealand waterfront reform was brought about when a port was closed for 34 days. When it was reopened the closed shop was actually broken. In Australia the farmers have replaced the loggers in New Zealand who actually opened up the waterfront. This government has done much to implement trade practices reforms that have strengthened and enhanced competition.
